Consecutive high blood pressures indicate this participant may be experiencing a hypertensive crisis. Refer to your site's SOP for expedited referral.

Participant could be in a hypotensive crisis if the participant is experiencing any symptoms of hemodynamic instability. Refer to your site's SOP for an emergent referral.

Hemodynamic instability is defined to include:
  1. Changes in mental status (reduced alertness and awareness, confusion, possible loss of consciousness)
  2. Chest pain
  3. Shortness of breath and/or rapid breathing
  4. Cold, clammy skin.
This value may indicate a hypertensive crisis if confirmed by a consecutive measure.
